citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult cavy on exhibit was observed to be less active than its pen mate and was holding its head in a lowered position
with its right eye closed. A large amount of thick yellow discharge was present in front of the eye; part of this discharge
appeared to have dried and become encrusted along the upper and lower eyelids. The fur around the eye appeared wet
and a serous discharge extended from the eye to the jawline. The facility director stated that this eye problem started 5
days earlier and was being treated in-house; however, an examination and diagnostic workup had not been done by a
veterinarian. Eye problems can be painful, can worsen quickly resulting in possible loss of vision, and can be contagious
to other animals. Holding the eye closed is often an indication of pain. The licensee must remove this animal from public
exhibit, must have the animal examined by a veterinarian, must follow the treatment protocol, and must provide written
medical records for review by the inspector.
To be completed by July 14, 2023.
Note: The licensee pulled this animal from exhibit and made an appointment with a veterinarian following the inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. Exit interviews were conducted on July 12
and 14, 2023.
Additional Inspectors:
ALICIA GRAVES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult cavy on exhibit was observed to be less active than its pen mate and was holding its head in a lowered position 
with its right eye closed. A large amount of thick yellow discharge was present in front of the eye; part of this discharge 
appeared to have dried and become encrusted along the upper and lower eyelids. The fur around the eye appeared wet 
and a serous discharge extended from the eye to the jawline. The facility director stated that this eye problem started 5 
days earlier and was being treated in-house; however, an examination and diagnostic workup had not been done by a 
veterinarian. Eye problems can be painful, can worsen quickly resulting in possible loss of vision, and can be contagious 
to other animals. Holding the eye closed is often an indication of pain. The licensee must remove this animal from public 
exhibit, must have the animal examined by a veterinarian, must follow the treatment protocol, and must provide written 
medical records for review by the inspector.  
 
To be completed by July 14, 2023. 
Note: The licensee pulled this animal from exhibit and made an appointment with a veterinarian following the inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. Exit interviews were conducted on July 12 
and 14, 2023. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ALICIA GRAVES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
